perturbation.original_text: If any Party pays any taxes that should have been borne by the other Party in accordance with Law, such other Party shall reimburse such Party within seven (7) days after its receipt of documentation evidencing such tax payment so incurred by such Party.
perturbation.changed_text: If any Party pays any taxes that should have been borne by the other Party in accordance with Law, such other Party shall reimburse such Party within one hundred and eighty (180) days after its receipt of documentation evidencing such tax payment so incurred by such Party.
perturbation.explanation: The original text specifies a reimbursement period of seven days for taxes paid on behalf of another party. This has been modified to one hundred and eighty days, which is likely an unreasonably long period and could violate regulations requiring prompt payment or reimbursement, potentially conflicting with tax laws mandating timely payments.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potentially violates PRC tax regulations requiring timely payment and reimbursement of tax-related expenses.

perturbation.original_text: Any Dispute which remains unresolved within sixty (60) days after the date of such written notice shall be submitted to the China International Economic and Trade Arbitration Commission (the "Commission") to be finally settled by arbitration in Beijing, PRC in accordance with the Commission's then effective rules (the "Rules") and this Section 10.12.
perturbation.changed_text: Any Dispute which remains unresolved within ten (10) days after the date of such written notice shall be submitted to the China International Economic and Trade Arbitration Commission (the "Commission") to be finally settled by arbitration in Beijing, PRC in accordance with the Commission's then effective rules (the "Rules") and this Section 10.12.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the dispute resolution period to ten days is extremely short and impractical. It may contradict the principles of fair dispute resolution processes which require sufficient time for parties to investigate, prepare, and negotiate. Such a short timeframe could be deemed unreasonable and unenforceable under PRC law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potentially violates PRC Arbitration Law and principles of natural justice requiring reasonable time for dispute resolution.

perturbation.original_text: Upon termination (but not expiration) of this Agreement for any reason, Licensee shall be entitled to use the Licensed Domain Names and Licensed Content for a limited period of time, not to exceed ninety (90) days, during which it shall diligently work to transition to another solution.
perturbation.changed_text: Upon termination (but not expiration) of this Agreement for any reason, Licensee shall be entitled to use the Licensed Domain Names and Licensed Content for a limited period of time, not to exceed fifteen (15) days, during which it shall diligently work to transition to another solution.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the transition period to fifteen days is unreasonably short, especially considering the complexities of transferring domain names and content. This may violate reasonable business practice principles and could be challenged as insufficient time to transition, potentially resulting in business disruption and related legal claims.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potentially violates PRC Contract Law related to reasonableness and fairness in contract terms, as well as potentially infringing upon reasonable business practices related to transitioning critical digital assets.
